document.title: NYS Learning Standards for English as a Second Language and the AERO ELA Framework

C2A6D9CCEBD64ACDB51FE367CD8AD2EA.description: Recognize and demonstrate an appreciation of some commonalities and distinctions across cultures and groups (differentiated by gender, ability, generations, etc.), including the students’ own. (L, S, R, W)

7888A2B2BE3645BAA6B3509ED7632B86.description: Compare and contrast oral traditions, myths, folktales, and literature from different national and international regions and cultures, including the students’ own, identifying similarities and differences and universal cultural themes, and exploring how language and literature transmit culture. (L, S, R, W)

913B689D54FE44B5ADA46B05E269D66F.description: Interpret and demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal and oral communication features, and understand the contexts in which they are used appropriately. Such means of nonverbal communication include gestures, body language, volume, stress, intonation, pace, rhythm, and pauses. (L, S)

1C7ECDE430E84B599EDBA6B26FA9AEB2.description: Recognize and share cross-cultural experiences and idea, and connect with those of others. (L, S, R, W)

008988786B4C4295B13C8EE16E1208E4.description: Demonstrate an understanding of a broad range of U.S. cultural and political referents through institutions, functions, and processes at the local and national levels, and compare/contrast these with parallels in the students’ native community. Such cultural and political referents include holidays, symbols, traditions, customs, governance systems, and schooling. (L, S, R, W)

BD61FC190EB4478AA3AEBA7AE0C2ABDA.description: Demonstrate an understanding of cultural and language patterns and norms in American English, including different regional and social varieties of English, and identify and interpret how these patterns and norms are used. Such patterns and norms include levels of formality, slang, humor, idioms, rhetorical patterns, and standard vs. nonstandard dialects (L, S, R, W)

7FC7BBF6CECA414A91AA1E42D779C3E5.description: Recognize and demonstrate an appreciation of some commonalities and distinctions across cultures and groups (differentiated by gender, ability, generations, etc.), including the students’ own. (L, S, R, W)

5BD1E85CFF65464A93BC544733C4CD51.description: Compare and contrast oral traditions, myths, folktales, and literature from the United States and international regions and cultures, including the students’ own, and identify similarities and differences and universal cultural themes. (L, S, R, W)

8B186656E09A46059CB6FA7E8C2C9B57.description: Interpret and demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal and oral communication features, and understand the contexts in which they are used appropriately. Such means of nonverbal communication include gestures, body language, volume, stress, intonation, and pace. (L, S)

71A9DB2DF7864532B1A06766F52D9D3E.description: Recognize and share cross-cultural experiences and idea, and connect with those of others. (L, S, R, W)

F0686E8ADB624EF5B8783B540960143A.description: Demonstrate an understanding of a broad range of U.S. cultural and political referents through institutions, functions, and processes at the local and national levels, and compare/contrast these with parallels in the students’ native community. Such cultural and political referents include holidays, symbols, traditions, customs, governance systems, and schooling. (L, S, R, W)

7F5B99917DE24C8AB7FAE57DABF72F26.description: Demonstrate an understanding of cultural and language patterns and norms in American English, including different regional and social varieties of English. Such patterns and norms include levels of formality, slang, humor, idioms, rhetorical patterns, and standard vs. nonstandard dialects. (L, S, R, W)

5F864F6A3D80492DAFB6F2CF32FFDEF7.description: Recognize and demonstrate an appreciation of some commonalities and distinctions across cultures and groups (differentiated by gender, ability, generations, etc.) including the students’ own. (L, S, R, W)

4EF3B2DF14D045AE8D313706FA009361.description: Read, listen to, and discuss myths, folktales, and literature from the United States and international regions and cultures, including the students’ own, and identify similarities and differences among them. (L, S, R, W)

5A3AB956C6064597AB41FD0A006B8DCC.description: Interpret and demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal and oral communication features, and understand the contexts in which they are used appropriately. Such features include gestures, body language, volume, stress, and intonation. (L, S)

3BA236E4A01F46CFBC4E98C382516AD7.description: Recognize and share cross-cultural experiences, and ideas, and connect with those of others. (L, S, R, W)

B17C969FEC4748619124BC235514C792.description: Demonstrate familiarity with a broad range of U.S. cultural and political referents through institutions, functions, and processes at the local and national levels. Such cultural and political referents include holidays, symbols, traditions, customs, governance systems, and schooling. (L, S, R, W)

6337AF0D3D4340D5A1FEEC84B1D60DAA.description: Demonstrate familiarity with cultural and language patterns and norms in American English. Such patterns and norms levels of formality, slang, humor, idioms, and rhetorical patterns. (L, S, R, W)

C9A33E531B284E7888324B7861DD7E55.description: STANDARD 5:  Students will demonstrate cross-cultural knowledge and understanding.

CF3570522DA744C4A5B1E458DF7A8D06.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies in social and classroom interactions. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative pronunciations or wording. (L, S, R, W)

D6E6F70EDA4143AB83CF85CC9740C66F.description: Discover alternative ways of saying things in social and classroom interactions. (L, S, R, W)

D9626AAFE84F47C4A2238C4DEC981746.description: Demonstrate appropriate classroom behaviors (e.g., participating in small group and whole class discussions, being courteous, respecting the person and property of others). (L, S, R, W)

7D490356000649BE9C9D7F4BBC88E107.description: Use appropriate vocabulary, expressions, language, routines, and interaction styles for various audiences and formal and informal social or school situations, noticing how intention is communicated in different ways through language in various contexts. Such expressions and routines include asking permission, making and responding to requests, greeting, making promises, thanking, and apologizing. Such situations include chatting with friends, participating in-group discussions, greeting a principal or other adult, making purchases, interviewing for a job, and applying to college. (L, S, R, W)

49AA8AFA54434DC3834910B5D906495B.description: Negotiate and manage interactions to accomplish social and classroom tasks. (L, S)

1733C54E40FD442A9210DCE1F34FF94B.description: Follow oral and written directions to participate in classroom activities, and provide directions to peers in selected interactions. (L, S, R, W)

E0EBC3A916D9481AAA2A116E30394078.description: Understand and use a variety of context-specific oral communication strategies in American English for a range of personal and academic purposes. Such strategies include making confirmation checks, clarifying or requesting clarification, paraphrasing, and repairing miscommunication. (L, S)

FB9EC12060B14EE69C95C4E6A4A0343B.description: Explain actions, choices, and decisions in social and academic situations. (S, W)

40BBD768CF1E4FE6BF92BABC00293858.description: Listen attentively, take turns speaking, and build on others’ ideas when engaged in pair, group, or full-class discussions on personal, social, community, and academic topics. (L, S)

3CFE3379C10E431FB5B67CEC482C57C1.description: Request and provide information and assistance, orally or in writing, for personal, social, and academic purposes. (L, S, R, W)

CFB52A1B1C6542329F2987700C1FF178.description: Describe, read about, participate in, or recommend a favorite activity, book, song, or other interest to various audiences. Such audiences include peer, class, teacher, and other adults. (L, S, R, W)

DAAB4079203444CD980588AC453E5F9E.description: Use a variety of oral, print, and electronic forms for social communication and for writing to or for self, applying the conventions of social writing. Such forms include friendly notes, invitations, and electronic messages, journal entries, and notes to self. (L, S, R, W)

07D876CB631746C98447A3586BC8ECCC.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies in social and classroom interactions. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L, S, R, W)

0D48EEA124054F3A8A92ACDA795704E1.description: Discover alternative ways of saying things in social and classroom interactions. (L, S, R, W)

0647DA3B4CF144F9B0CD776FFC51067D.description: Demonstrate appropriate classroom behaviors (e.g., participating in small group and whole class discussions, being courteous, respecting the person and property of others). (L, S, R, W)

F7C998F6161648FE9AA3F94C308E1F94.description: Use appropriate vocabulary, expressions, language, routines, and interaction styles for various audiences and formal and informal social or school situations, noticing how intention is realized through language. Such expressions and routines include asking permission, making and responding to requests, greeting, making promises, thanking, and apologizing. Such situations include chatting with friends, participating in group discussions, greeting a principal or other adult, making purchases. (L, S, R, W)

7B2EBBE952F24F119CB228990F366451.description: Negotiate and manage interactions to accomplish social and classroom tasks. (L, S)

87D7722648234C1AA7C01BA5566A0049.description: Follow oral and written directions to participate in classroom and social activities, and provide directions to peers in selected interactions. (L, S, R, W)

10C98446C4BA4BDD8B0B52FB69A671DD.description: Understand and use a variety of oral communication strategies in American English for various social and academic purposes. Such strategies include making confirmation checks, clarifying or requesting clarification, paraphrasing, and repairing miscommunication. (L, S)

0A1BC60CE38946EF976FB76260A48470.description: Explain actions, choices, and decisions in social and academic situations. (S, W)

38349904CBCE4CE0831995BEC50FCE5C.description: Listen attentively, take turns speaking, and build on others’ ideas when engaged in pair, group, or full-class discussions on personal, social, community, and academic topics. (L, S)

5ECBA8A487DD41EBB76B0ECBF80A80FF.description: Request and provide information and assistance, orally or in writing, for personal, social, and academic purposes. (L, S, R, W)

CC9E0F83E89F466F81AF92574E39D50E.description: Describe, read about, participate in, or recommend a favorite activity, book, song, or other interest to various audiences. Such audiences include peer, class, teacher, and other adults. (L, S, R, W)

2FE6AB2DDE174750AEAE045DEFADD22D.description: Use a variety of oral, print, and electronic forms for social communication and for writing to or for self, applying the conventions of social writing. Such forms include friendly notes, invitations, and electronic messages, diary entries, and notes to self. (L, S, R, W)

5EFB0141490B432DB75EA85978C76A43.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies in social and classroom interactions. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L, S, R, W)

1142686589224AEA8CD2A7BBD7F360A6.description: Discover alternative ways of saying things in social and classroom interactions. (L, S, R, W)

9365A867C1A54DCC847642956833BD4C.description: Demonstrate appropriate classroom behaviors (e.g., participating in small group and whole class discussions, being courteous, respecting the person and property of others). (L, S, R, W)

F7DFB2B24BBF4D508412AAC8EFF5F4E5.description: Use appropriate vocabulary, expressions, language, routines, and interaction styles for various audiences and formal and informal social or school situations. Such expressions and routines include asking permission, making and responding to requests, greeting, making promises, thanking, and apologizing. Such situations include chatting with friends, participating in group discussions, greeting a principal or other adult, and making purchases. (L, S, R, W)

9B3C54E297C7478AA9C89DAAA5EC6069.description: Negotiate and manage interactions to accomplish social and classroom tasks. (L, S)

094B04A2E903448F94E20321F27F63BC.description: Follow oral and written directions to participate in classroom and social activities. (L, R)

4D25621E139B4D4284363A8E7F3D35ED.description: Understand and use a variety of oral communication strategies in American English for various social and academic purposes. Such strategies include indicating lack of understanding, clarifying or requesting clarification, restatement, and checking listeners’ understanding. (L, S)

DD9219318E144630B49B9DE37FB2352C.description: Explain actions, choices, and decisions in social and academic situations. (S, W)

73C9525078B041E7BF90A167DF9CC03D.description: Listen attentively and take turns speaking when engaged in pair, group, or full-class discussions on personal, social, and academic topics. (L, S)

ED84E61C041745EC8FE96E7171CF03C2.description: Request and provide information and assistance, orally or in writing, for personal, social, and academic purposes. (L, S, R, W)

E166CEBB152247508CB7774FAF81CE9A.description: Describe, read about, participate in, or recommend a favorite activity, book, song, or other interest to various audiences. Such audiences include peer, class, teacher, and other adults. (L, S, R, W)

3308C65F28A746D4A573D0E31E75474B.description: Use a variety of oral, print, and electronic forms for social communication and for writing to or for self, applying the conventions of social writing. Such forms include friendly notes, invitations, and electronic messages, journal entries, and notes to self. (L, S, R, W)

A1098D3E65D84B0CB66DBFAC692F2E49.description: STANDARD 4:  Students will listen, speak, read, and write in English for classroom and social interaction.

9BE006BF0DAB4A16BA984DBF16864C91.description: Apply learning strategies to examine, interpret, analyze, synthesize, and evaluate a variety of materials. Such strategies include using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; and exploring cognates and root words. (L, S, R, W)

1B378720B12348BFBFA0F3BEFA0B1D03.description:
Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies using established criteria for effective oral and written presentation and standards for a particular genre (e.g., debate, speech, argument) to adjust presentation and language production to effectively express opinions and evaluations. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things.
(L, S, R, W)

9A8C8F19D8DF4BEDBA69B5562149E108.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of groupings to discuss, share, reflect on, develop, and express, and to interpret opinions and evaluations about a variety of experiences, ideas, and information. Such groupings include small groups, discussion groups, process writing groups, and cooperative learning groups. (L, S, R, W)

282DCACF0BD2403AB5300F3290E705CA.description: Speak and write, using the conventions and features of American English, to effectively influence an audience (e.g., to persuade, negotiate, argue). Such spoken language features include appropriate grammar, precise vocabulary, pronunciation, intonation, and presentation strategies. Such written language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, correct spelling, punctuation, and capitalization. (S, W)

51EC9454FF304B539D563DD880B39E19.description: Recognize, explain, evaluate, and analyze how structural features affect readers’ and listeners’ understanding and appreciation of text. Such features include organization, syntax, repetition of words or ideas, vocabulary, and visuals. (L, S, R, W)

9FA10E3ED3634874B90B2FA8F2E63866.description: Evaluate students’ own and others’ work, individually and collaboratively, on the basis of a variety of criteria, and recognize how chosen criteria affect evaluation. Criteria include visual presentation; clarity of ideas; logic; originality; comprehensiveness; and use of English vocabulary, grammar, and register. (L, S, R, W)

3CB4827D66694427B6F91E273B4F5DAF.description: Recognize and communicate personal and multiple points of view within and among groups, in discussing, interpreting, and evaluating information, make inferences about a writer’s or speaker’s point of view. (L, S, R, W)

0316E1D40A2143DD953AABA838F90C10.description: Assess, compare, and evaluate the quality of spoken or written texts and visual presentations, using different criteria related to the organization, subject area, and purpose of text. Text types include editorials, letters to the editors, political speeches, illustrations, charts, movie/textbook/book reviews, and advertisements. (L, S, R, W)

37CFF061FD5849C2AB40641C418DD702.description: Develop and present clear interpretations, analyses, and evaluations of issues, ideas, texts, and experiences; justify and explain the rationale for positions, using persuasive language, tone, evidence, and well-developed arguments. Forms of such presentations include oral (class presentations, speeches, and debates), visual (posters, graphs, charts, political cartoons, and illustrations), and written (essays, editorials, movie/textbook/book reviews, position papers, and brochures). (L, S, R, W)

975F96545F434D2FBA3E2F4C786EBCC6.description: Apply learning strategies to examine, interpret, and evaluate a variety of materials. Such strategies include using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; and exploring cognates and root words. (L, S, R, W)

A6B4DB3CFE6B4A70A6494C919DEE26AA.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies using established criteria for effective oral and written presentation and standards for a particular genre (e.g., debate, speech, argument) to adjust presentation and language production to effectively express opinions and evaluations. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L, S, R, W)

B7FCCD0372334772AD11C0C536D5B35F.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of groupings to discuss, share, reflect on, develop, and express, and to interpret opinions and evaluations about a variety of experiences, ideas, and information. Such groupings include small groups, discussion groups, process writing groups, and cooperative learning groups. (L, S, R, W)

A15CFCBEE78940228FB20B74A3E3CB96.description: Speak and write, using the conventions and features of American English, to effectively influence an audience (e.g., to persuade, negotiate, argue). Such spoken language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, pronunciation, and intonation. Such written language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, correct spelling, punctuation, and capitalization. (S, W)

D30FF5FB91D34635BA4B4D03903FFDCC.description: Recognize, explain, and evaluate how structural features affect readers’ and listeners’ understanding and appreciation of text. Such features include organization, syntax, repetition of words or ideas, vocabulary, and visuals. (L, S, R, W)

FEAF05A282174CDD9A166F11C92C0238.description: Evaluate students’ own and others’ work, individually and collaboratively, on the basis of a variety of criteria. Criteria include visual presentation; clarity of ideas; logic; originality; comprehensiveness; and use of English vocabulary, grammar, and register. (L, S, R, W)

7225399A9D7F492DBCD14D8D8ACD5686.description: Recognize and communicate personal and multiple points of view within and among groups, in discussing, interpreting, and evaluating information in texts and presentations. (L, S, R, W)

5AFB0984903E43B09CDCA4E318B161E0.description: Assess, compare, and evaluate the quality of spoken or written texts and visual presentations, using different criteria related to the organization, subject area, and purpose of text. Text types include editorials, letters to the editor, political speeches, illustrations, charts, and advertisements. (L, S, R, W)

C5266654D6D34A15BA64C6C142E9C6B6.description: Develop and present clear interpretations, analyses, and evaluations of issues, ideas, texts, and experiences, supporting positions with well-developed arguments.  Forms of such presentations include oral (class presentations, speeches, and debates), visual (posters, graphs, charts, and illustrations), and written (essays, position papers, brochures). (L, S, R, W)

A8F914A4474B4DB6BA66FB0321A42EEA.description: Apply learning strategies to examine and interpret a variety of materials. Such strategies include using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; and exploring cognates and root words. (L, S, R, W)

D28C40B6CBB645EEAA0BDCA47E095E4B.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies using established criteria for effective oral and written presentation to adjust presentation and language production to effectively express opinions and evaluations. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L, S, R, W)

4B34254832934CCBA74EDC5A0E043417.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of groupings to discuss, share, reflect on, develop, and express opinions and evaluations about a variety of experiences, ideas, and information. Such groupings include small groups, discussion groups, process writing groups, and cooperative learning groups. (L, S, R, W)

C1263C1155894F80B0949EFCA670510C.description: Speak and write, using the conventions and features of American English, to effectively influence an audience (e.g., to persuade, negotiate, argue). Such spoken language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, pronunciation, and intonation. Such written language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, correct spelling, punctuation, and capitalization. (S, W)

04B921BF3BB14879866A69B874D0E3C4.description: Recognize and explain how structural features affect readers’ and listeners’ understanding and appreciation of text. Such features include organization, syntax, repetition of words or ideas, vocabulary, and visuals. (L, S, R, W)

96BE37978B634CAC8FD95C7F6DA50F13.description: Evaluate students’ own and others’ work, individually and collaboratively, on the basis of a variety of criteria. Criteria include visual presentation; clarity of ideas; logic; originality; comprehensiveness; and use of English vocabulary, grammar, and register. (L, S, R, W)

8D7C636BAEBD41B5996A94DD553155A4.description: Recognize personal point of view in self and others in discussing, interpreting, and evaluating information. (L, S, R, W)

14B96CCD396D44AE84343A017E7F6733.description: Evaluate the quality and dependability of written or spoken texts and visual presentations, on the basis of established criteria; and evaluate the logic and believability of claims made in persuasive material such as an advertisement. (L, S, R, W)

7F406E2639054B7E92253C0F01D65C7F.description: Form and express responses to a variety of literary, informational, and persuasive material through reading, listening, viewing, discussing, and writing; use details and evidence as support. (L, S, R, W)

75E3D65A2C4447F7A892D71FCC52BE66.description: Standard 3:  Students will listen, speak, read, and write in English for critical analysis and evaluation.

49D3813EB45B401DB4A9E14F82F93230.description: Apply learning strategies to comprehend, make inferences about, and analyze literature, and to produce literary responses. Such strategies include asking questions, using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; and exploring cognates and root words. (L, S, R, W)

245C41F6AB9F4FB7A30C3AFECAF964DF.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies while reading, viewing, discussing, listening to, or producing literary texts and essays. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L. S, R, W)

6F8C5DBFEDE149F5AFBF67BDA40C5D77.description: Create, discuss, interpret, and respond to literary works using appropriate and effective vocabulary, grammar, spelling, and punctuation in writing, and using appropriate vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation in speaking. (L. S, R, W)

C5958D68567440858F38DDF1C0C69101.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of student groupings to create and respond to literature. Such groupings include small groups, cooperative learning groups, literature circles, and process writing groups. (L. S, R, W)

DA814D5BF8474FDFA836BDA67B70879C.description: Create stories, poems, sketches, songs, and plays, including those that reflect traditional and popular American culture, using typical features of a given genre; create an effective voice, using a variety of writing styles appropriate to different audiences, purposes, and settings. (S, W)

E4F22A8AF0F74CF0ADD19A97E9468B69.description: Compose and present personal and formal responses to and interpretations of published literary works and the work of peers, referring to details and features of text. Such features include characters, setting, plot, ideas, events, vocabulary, and text structure. (L, S, R, W)

2A15E762098946EDBBA1D263737FC4BB.description: Read aloud with confidence, accuracy, fluency, and expression to demonstrate understanding and to convey an interpretation of meaning. (S, R)

3A789CABE0674D5ABB73B98880057001.description: Make predictions, inferences, and deductions, and describe different levels of meaning of literary works presented orally and in written form, including literal and implied meanings. Strategies include summarizing; explaining; and identifying word choice, point of view, and symbols. (L, S, R, W)

945302C4F17A44338AC825561F818CA5.description: Locate and identify a wide range of significant literary elements and techniques in texts and use those elements to interpret the work, comparing and contrasting the work to other works and to students’ own experiences. Such elements include setting, character, plot, theme, point of view, figurative language, text structure, repetition, characterization, imagery, foreshadowing, and climax. (S, R, W)

CD029FDAA6A54379BAB48CE04DECBBDC.description: Identify and explain the distinguishing features of different literary genres, periods, and traditions, and use those features to aid comprehension, interpretation, and discussion of literature. (S, R, W)

9DD97776A9B54636B5B1C4CFA013281A.description: Apply reading and listening strategies to make literary text comprehensible and meaningful. Such strategies include skimming, scanning, previewing, reviewing, listening selectively, listening for a specific purpose, and listening for main ideas and details. (L, R)

7EB49DFE82874B59854546761EA4FB85.description: Read, listen to, view, and discuss a variety of texts from a wide range of authors, subjects, genres, cultures, and historical periods. Such sources include poems, stories, myths, fables, plays, novels, and other fiction and nonfiction texts, in authentic and modified forms, including works of American popular culture. (L, S, R)

9F245F04F834405F952B72068DFF8EED.description: Apply learning strategies to comprehend and make inferences about literature and produce literary responses. Such strategies include asking questions, using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; and exploring cognates and root words. (L, S, R, W)

90959ABBFC98431384DC5851A5295A5D.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies while reading, viewing, discussing, listening to, or producing literary texts and essays. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L. S, R, W)

102BD9CB5AB94C9394B5AC87F9C0D4EA.description: Create, discuss, interpret, and respond to literary works using appropriate and effective vocabulary, grammar, spelling, and punctuation in writing, and using appropriate vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation in speaking. (L. S, R, W)

35DB29C8B26E4A8A803AB2E0A0AD06FD.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of student groupings to create and respond to literature. Such groupings include small groups, cooperative learning groups, literature circles, and process writing groups. (L. S, R, W)

34CFFDC83C4D43799F89943F20EDF459.description: Create stories, poems, songs, and plays, including those that reflect traditional and popular American culture, observing the conventions of the genre; create an effective voice, using a variety of writing styles appropriate to different audiences, purposes, and settings. (S, W)

7656395443C9433E8051BB52B9134BE4.description: Compose and present personal and formal responses to and interpretations of published literary works and the work of peers, referring to details and features of text. Such features include characters, setting, plot, ideas, events, vocabulary, and text structure. (L, S, R, W)

C2C12EEE98B34795916A83CDA48B2DAF.description: Read aloud with confidence, accuracy, and fluency. (S, R)

92F4CC107D1D42F7BD76618D60B3356F.description: Make predictions, inferences, and deductions, and describe different levels of meaning of literary works presented orally and in written form, including literal and implied meanings. Strategies include summarizing; explaining; and identifying word choice, point of view, and symbols. (L, S, R, W)

BCB5FDFF489948C685887316B0167377.description: Locate and identify selected literary elements and techniques in texts and relate those elements to those in other works and to students’ own experiences. Such elements include setting, character, plot, theme, point of view, repetition, characterization, imagery, foreshadowing, and climax. (S, R, W)

974199D5C5AB4ED4A32203131BFC9BF6.description: Identify and explain the distinguishing features of the major genres, and use those features to aid comprehension, interpretation, and discussion of literature. (S, R, W)

836E57BA262843CC96F16CFC4D21B7F5.description: Identify and use reading and listening strategies to make literary text comprehensible and meaningful. Such strategies include skimming, scanning, previewing, reviewing, listening selectively, listening for a specific purpose, and listening for main ideas and details. (L, R)

0623C4A2EA1F40AD90BAD9BF831FE1D0.description:
Read, listen to, view, and discuss texts and performances from a wide range of authors, subjects and genres. Such sources include picture books, myths, fables, poems, stories, plays, novels and other fiction and nonfiction texts in authentic and modified forms, including works of American popular culture.
(L, S, R)

5ECC36FAE3084199894A50236C335A93.description: Apply learning strategies to comprehend and make inferences about literature and produce literary responses. Such strategies include asking questions, using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; and exploring cognates and root words. (L, S, R, W)

17F640CD700D4BC5AC30E1F545F93F52.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies while reading, viewing, discussing, listening to, or producing literary texts and essays. Such strategies include asking questions, starting over, rephrasing, and exploring alternative ways of saying things. (L. S, R, W)

97FD353785584F61878D25AAFCD1E2AD.description: Create, discuss, interpret, and respond to literary works using appropriate and effective vocabulary, grammar, spelling, and punctuation in writing, and using appropriate vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation in speaking. (L. S, R, W)

77897B0B9ECE4A7A8AE11E2941791400.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of student groupings to create and respond to literature. Such groupings include small groups, cooperative learning groups, literature circles, and process writing groups. (L. S, R, W)

D6DB0F1A34594836991DF1BC4BCD045B.description: Create personal stories, poems, and songs, including those that reflect traditional and popular American culture; use appropriate vocabulary and elements of the literature students have read or heard. (S, W)

690CD76EF9844ABA80A3CDAA9FF68EF5.description: Compose and present personal and formal responses to published literature and the work of peers, referring to details and features of text. Such features include characters, setting, plot, ideas, events, vocabulary, and text structure. (L, S, R, W)

92B63E7CBEAD4D24A1E1B9AA341010C5.description: Read aloud with confidence, accuracy, and fluency. (S, R)

036086BDA1564CC68698CE8957E3A2B4.description: Make predictions, inferences, and deductions, and discuss the meaning of literary works with some attention to meaning beyond the literal level, to understand and interpret text presented orally and in written form. (L, S, R)

0D843CD7A11B4047947D5532235D61B1.description: Locate and identify key literary elements in texts and relate those elements to those in other works and to students’ own experiences. Such elements include setting, character, plot, theme, repetition, and point of view. (S, R)

80BF3AF78F1C488382C6385A04D6F747.description: Recognize some features that distinguish some genres and use those features to aid comprehension. (S, R)

923F177632834AA48E1498EE6A57B838.description: Identify and use reading and listening strategies to make literary text comprehensible and meaningful. Such strategies include skimming, scanning, previewing, reviewing, listening selectively or for a specific purpose, and listening for main ideas and details. (L, R)

E372A8B9A25A4BDDA1FF850760716917.description: Read, listen to, view, and discuss a variety of literature of different genres. Such genres include picture books, poems, articles and stories from magazines, fables, myths and legends, songs, plays and media productions, and works of fiction and nonfiction, including works of American popular culture. (L, S, R)

8E88C57C8E664E10830521F3C4BABF52.description: STANDARD 2:  Students will listen, speak, read, and write in English for literary response, enjoyment, and expression.

F489432EB233454E9445200A2EF277A8.description: Apply learning strategies to acquire information and make texts comprehensible and meaningful. Such strategies include using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, reference materials, and context cues; planning; note taking; questioning; exploring cognates and root words; and applying ideas to new settings or experiences. (L, S, R, W)

BD79E06B821049908689BD14BE0016AC.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies for accurate language production and oral and written presentation, using established criteria for effective presentation of information. (L, S, R, W)

50E575ECF5C54A61B46E40ED5F457B31.description: Consult print and non-print resources (e.g., audio/visual media, family) in the native language when needed. (L, S, R)

BBFEC539E8EC4E9FB5EFA2853DF0A799.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of student groupings to read, gather, share, discuss, interpret, organize, analyze, synthesize, and present information. Such groupings include small groups, cooperative learning groups, process writing groups, cross-age groupings, research groups, and interest groups. (L, S, R, W)

336514AD21934058A2180308A8E2DFA3.description: Convey information and ideas through spoken and written language, using conventions and features of American English appropriate to audience and purpose. Such spoken language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, pronunciation, and intonation. Such written language features include appropriate grammar, vocabulary, correct spelling, punctuation, capitalization, paragraphing, and a wide variety of sentence structures. (L, S, R, W)

43FE7297DCAF4012930686BCC52D3DC9.description: Use the process of prewriting, drafting, revising, peer editing, and proofreading (the “writing process”) to produce well-constructed informational texts. (L, S, R, W)

B6CDFBA8EF2D4033BE0AE681F984F3A2.description: Distinguish between fact and opinion, and relevant and irrelevant information, and exclude nonessential information in oral and written presentations. (S, W)

F505D5284469441FA91780FE011D95D6.description: Convey and organize information, using facts, details, illustrative examples, and a variety of patterns and structures. Such patterns and structures include chronological order, cause and effect, problem and solution, and general-to-specific presentation. (S, W)

0E2F1BDB22D54DDB8261695C08F87CBD.description: Select a focus, organization, and point of view for oral and written presentations, and justify this selection. (S, W)

65EC09BB32A248CFB6373CF252BB8282.description: Present information clearly in a variety of oral and written forms for different audiences and purposes related to all academic content areas. Such forms include paraphrases, summaries, stories, research reports, essays, articles, posters, charts, and other graphics. (S, W)

4337AF7BD00B4B2EB7DBC3B5FB85CFD5.description: Support inferences about information and ideas with reference to features in oral and written text. Such features include vocabulary, format, facts, sequence, register, and relevance of details. (L, S, R, W)

AED2C53E13124162B9543F18B13FBB13.description: Formulate, ask, and respond to various questions forms to obtain, clarify, and extend information and meaning. (L, S, R, W)

B6ACD981DF3E4BC1968A4BE9F3725931.description: Compare, contrast, categorize, and synthesize information and objects, and identify complexities and discrepancies in the information. (L, S, R, W)

138938DEA01147058B4098F29D4C2F52.description: Select information appropriate to the purpose of the investigation with suitable supporting material. Such material includes facts, details, illustrative examples, anecdotes, and personal experiences. (L, S, R, W)

95B5B3542BEF4E16B337852FDBCA58AE.description: Read, gather, view, listen to, organize, discuss, interpret, and analyze information related to academic content areas from various sources. Such sources include nonfiction books for young adults, reference books, magazines, textbooks, the Internet, databases, audio and media presentations, oral interviews, charts, graphs, maps, and diagrams. (L, S, R, W)

C31F242C17614A01B0B4ED6FB88B252D.description: Identify and use reading and listening strategies to make text comprehensible and meaningful. Such strategies include skimming; scanning; previewing; reviewing; discussing, listening selectively; listening for a specific purpose; listening for main ideas and details; note taking; using structural and context clues, cognates, format, sequence, and an understanding of letter-sound relationships to decode difficult words. (L, R)

536B21200D9147B9B8563B17DED1CB1F.description: Apply learning strategies to acquire information and make texts comprehensible and meaningful. Such strategies include using prior knowledge, graphic organizers, and context cues; planning; note taking; inferencing; questioning; exploring cognates and root words; and applying ideas to new settings or experiences. (L, S, R, W)

4474558C321B4978ADBF8FF1E274890A.description: Apply self-monitoring and self-correcting strategies for accurate language production and oral and written presentation, using established criteria for effective presentation of information. (L, S, R, W)

9D666360CB1844E8B44CB9F8C9BFE95E.description: Consult print and non-print resources (e.g., audio/visual media, family) in the native language when needed. (L, S, R)

FE5368D73CC54047A5C858D82D6CE3B9.description: Engage in collaborative activities through a variety of student groupings to read, gather, share, discuss, interpret, organize, analyze, and present information. 6E50223991C0411E97ADEE953DAF170F.description: Convey information and ideas through spoken and written language, using conventions and features of American English appropriate to audience and purpose. 3D1456FD748444349CBE23F3FC1FC317.description: Present information clearly in a variety of oral and written forms for different audiences and purposes related to all academic content areas. 1D80BACB58FD4DBC8A0C9A3D297AAE8B.description: Formulate, ask, and respond to various question forms to obtain, clarify, and extend information and meaning. (L, S, R, W)

5FE721B12F6845AB89E99F62CE68AAC4.description: Compare, contrast, categorize, and synthesize to gain a deeper understanding of information and objects. (L, S, R, W)

2901D8EF99984E05A76978B259EA4226.description: Select information appropriate to the purpose of the investigation, relate ideas from one written or spoken source to another, and exclude nonessential information. (L, S, R, W)

1400F5F8C56F4090B42AC7BEE1594663.description: Read, gather, view, listen to, organize, discuss, interpret, and analyze information related to academic content areas from various sources. Such sources include nonfiction books for young adults, reference books, magazines, textbooks, the Internet, databases, audio and media presentations, oral interviews, charts, graphs, maps, and diagrams. (L, S, R, W)

C7F2B8DAD759467095DED55CDAD10A9C.description: Consult print and non-print resources (e.g., audio/visual media, family) in the native language when needed. (L, S, R)

C3915BFD7CCB4B218DB5443E2485E3CD.description: Distinguish between fact and opinion, and relevant and irrelevant information. (S, W)

4AF096DD777E4EDCA3086FC83703FC22.description: Convey information, using a variety of organizational patterns and structures. Such patterns and structures include chronological order, cause and effect, similarities and differences, and general-to-specific presentation. (S, W)

A541896A5C1F4AB6A14A2861515DFE2D.description: Select a focus, organization, and point of view for oral and written presentations. (S, W)

C5F39A44D4E746178B80E8963F1D77F2.description: Present information clearly in a variety of oral and written forms for different audiences and purposes related to all academic content areas. 03C800345F70440C8B6407A46AA48A56.description: Support inferences about information and ideas with reference to features in oral and written text. Such features include vocabulary, facts, sequence, and details. (L, S, R, W)

7F827F21E6F245599631BEFCFE3364F8.description:
Formulate, ask, and respond to questions to obtain, clarify, and extend information and meaning.

Compare, contrast, and categorize, to gain a deeper understanding of information and objects.

45C4F7E008BD4468B4D2F8AE17B7D709.description: Select information appropriate to the purpose of the investigation, and relate ideas from one written or spoken source to another. (L, S, R, W)

7681F61592CD4AE5B1638EF628075657.description: Read, gather, view, listen to, organize, discuss, and interpret information related to academic content areas from various sources. EB53E1D26E88487EA41F283562EBB178.description: STANDARD 1 - Students will listen, speak, read, and write in English for information and understanding.
